Q: How do you find the cluster & service CIDR of a Kubernetes cluster? A:

To find your Kubernetes cluster's CIDR, you typically need to look for two separate ranges: the Service CIDR (for Service IPs) and the Pod CIDR (for Pod IPs). The method depends on your Kubernetes version and how it was set up.

  1. Service CIDR (ClusterIP range)

  • Kubernetes v1.33+: For clusters running Kubernetes version 1.33 or newer, a dedicated API resource exists: kubectl get servicecidrs -o jsonpath='{.items[*].spec.cidrs}'

  • Older Versions: kubectl cluster-info dump --all-namespaces | grep "service-cluster-ip-range"

For minikube:

If you're using minikube, the service CIDR might be located in the config.json file within your ~/.minikube directory: cat ~/.minikube/config.json | grep ServiceCIDR

  1. Pod CIDR (Network range)

The pod network CIDR defines the IP addresses available for your pods.

  • Inspecting individual Nodes: You can retrieve the specific pod CIDR assigned to each node: kubectl get nodes -o jsonpath='{.items[*].spec.podCIDR}' This works if the field is populated in your configuration.

  • Inspecting kube-controller-manager configuration: For self-managed clusters (like those set up with kubeadm), you can inspect the controller manager's configuration file on the master node: cat /etc/kubernetes/manifests/kube-controller-manager.yaml | grep cluster-cidr Or check active processes: ps -ef | grep "cluster-cidr"

  • Inspecting CNI-specific resources: The Pod CIDR often depends on the Container Network Interface (CNI) plugin you are using (e.g., Calico, Flannel).

    • Calico: kubectl get ippools -o yaml | awk '/cidr:/ {print $2}'
    • Flannel: kubectl -n kube-flannel get configmap kube-flannel-cfg -o yaml | grep '"Network"' | awk -F '"' '{print $4}'

Q: SwiftUI ScrollView + LazyVStack: expanding a cell causes it to scroll out of view — how to keep the expanded item visible? A:

I would suggest keeping the ScrollViewReader + scrollTo solution.

However, if you intend to use iOS 18+, then go with a native solution.

  1. ScrollPosition Binding: You create a state object that tracks the scrollable area's identity and provides a direct scrollTo(id:) method.

  2. scrollTargetLayout(): This modifier is applied to the inner container (like LazyVStack) to tell SwiftUI that the items within it are the valid targets for positioning.

  3. Identity-Based Alignment: When you trigger a scroll to a specific ID, SwiftUI calculates the new height of the expanded card and automatically adjusts the offset to keep that ID centered in the viewport.

Q: How to compare two dates? A:

With python as the easiest language available it is pretty easy to compare dates in python the python operators <, > and == fit wonderfully with datetime objects. each of them has their own meaning in python:

  • < means the date is earlier than the first
  • > means the date comes later
  • == means the date is same as the first So, for your case:
import datetime

date = datetime.datetime(2000, 1, 1) # Replace with whatever you want
now = datetime.datetime.now() # You can even find the current date and time using this expression

if date < now:
    print('past')
elif date > now:
    print('future')
else:
    print('present')
# This would print "past"

Q: Git - deleted some files locally, how do I get them from a remote repository A:

Since git is a distributed VCS, your local repository contains all of the information. No downloading is necessary; you just need to extract the content you want from the repo at your fingertips.

If you haven't committed the deletion, just check out the files from your current commit:

git checkout HEAD <path>...

The path(s) can be one or more file or directory.

If you have committed the deletion, you need to check out the files from a commit that has them. Presumably it would be the previous commit:

git checkout HEAD^ <path>

but if it's n commits ago, use HEAD~n.

(That parameter can be any rev-like, e.g. a branch. You could even simply find a commit in a GUI repository browser, copy its hash, and paste it into the command line.)

Q: Convert raw SQL containing DISTINCT, GROUP_CONCAT(), JOINs, parenthetical WHERE logic, GROUP BY, and LIMIT to CodeIgniter's query builder A:

I don't know how much of your SQL is dynamic in your application, but let's say you are in your Carrier_model. Here is how you could chain query builder methods and return an array of objects.

The use of an array in the select() call will allow plain columns to be quoted automatically. The Artists column expression contains a parenthesis (as well as a single quote) so no auto-quoting will be performed.

The odd-check (bitwise expression) in the where clause will also not receive auto-quoting because it contains a parenthesis.

I added the ?: null fallback in the where_in() call in case it is possible for an empty array to be supplied. Otherwise, an empty array would cause an invalid query to be rendered (and executed).

Everything else is a straight conversion which assumes that your raw SQL actually works as intended.

Note, for best portability, it may be a good idea to explicitly name all non-aggregate columns when grouping instead of only mentioning the ID.
->group_by(['c.ID', 'c.Title', 'c.VersionInfo'])

public function getWithArtistNames(array $sourceIds): array
{
return $this->db
    ->distinct()
    ->select([
        'c.ID',
        'c.Title',
        'c.VersionInfo',
        "GROUP_CONCAT(DISTINCT i.FullName ORDER BY cma.Ranking SEPARATOR ', ') AS Artists"
    ])
    ->from('carriermodifications cm')
    ->join('carriers c', 'cm.CarrierID = c.ID')
    ->join('carriermainartists cma', 'cma.CarrierID = c.ID', 'left')
    ->join('identities i', 'cma.IdentityID = i.ID', 'left')
    ->join('carriermainartists scma', 'scma.CarrierID = c.ID')
    ->join('identities si', 'scma.IdentityID = si.ID')
    ->where_in('cm.DataSourceID', $sourceIds ?: null)
    ->where([
        'c.Verified' => 1,
        'c.Hidden' => 0,
        '(c.Filter & 1)' => 1,
    ])
    ->group_start()
        ->or_where([
            'si.Nationality' => 2,
            'c.Concept' => 4,
        ])
    ->group_end()
    ->group_by('c.ID')
    ->order_by('cm.ModificationDate', 'desc')
    ->limit(27)
    ->get()
    ->result();
}

And the call site could look like this:

$result = $this->Carrier_model->getWithArtistNames([16, 17]);

POGOs and Legal/Financial Issues

  • POGOs (Philippine Offshore Gaming Operators) are online gambling firms licensed by PAGCOR but primarily serving overseas clients.

  • Controversies:

    • Taxation: Many POGOs have been accused of tax evasion.

    • Labor: Large influx of foreign workers, sometimes without proper permits.

    • Security: Concerns about money laundering and links to organized crime.

  • Cloud Gaming & Finance: The rise of online/cloud-based gambling makes regulation harder, since servers and financial flows can be offshore, complicating jurisdiction.

Internal Finance Implications

  • Revenue vs. Risk: While POGOs brought billions in revenue, they also created risks for internal finance stability (e.g., illicit capital flows, reputational damage).

  • Policy Shift: The Philippine government has increasingly cracked down, with some POGOs being shut down or relocated.

  • International Pressure: Neighboring countries (like China) have pressured the Philippines to curb POGOs, arguing they target Chinese citizens illegally.

Big Picture

  • U.S. vs. Philippines: The U.S. focuses on trade fairness and consumer protection, while the Philippines faces challenges of balancing economic gains from POGOs with legal, financial, and international obligations.

  • Lesson: When industries like offshore gaming grow faster than regulatory frameworks, they can distort internal finance and invite external scrutiny
